content.text: Your personal and private AI Workbook

You can think of a Jot like a file on a computer.  The same way a file can be a word doc, a piece of code, or a full app - a  Jot can function as a note, an AI enabled dynamic document, and/or an executable app.
It is a single application to take notes, create resources, chat with AI, and build automations.
Jot runs similar to a  piece of code, from top to bottom (like a Jupyter Notebook). However, a Jot is written and configured with natural language in the form of a document.
Even if you have never coded before, after reading this tutorial, you will be able to make full AI tools, apps, and documents... or just a plain old regular note!
Activate all the default triggers.  The last trigger - "Other" - allows you to capture anything.
Add Jot ContextBrain to your Applications Folder.
Open Jot ContextBrain, Copy the ContextURL, and add it to the:
Jot Chrome Extension pop up (you can find this beside the search bar, in the extension menu in chrome)
Jot Side Menu (⬅️ Open the menu in the top left of Jot and scroll to the bottom)
(Sorry for the set up but this allows all of your application information that is captured to be stored privately and locally on your computer)

P.S. You can close the tab for the Jot ContextBrain, it runs in the background.  It also will appear in the top right of your mac if you ever need it!  If it does not appear in the top right, the Context Block will not work!
Other than being a note editor, Jot has 4 main features to learn:
/ opens the menu to access all of Jot's features.
An AI Block can be inserted by typing a
/  .  This is what an AI Block looks like:
Hi! How can I assist you with your note or any other questions you might have?
An AI Block is like an AI chatbot that has access to everything above it.  It does not have memory of previous questions, only what is above it in the Jot.

attrs.query:
What is x? 

What is my favourite ice cream?

content.text: I don't have information about your favorite ice cream.
My favourite ice cream is Mint Chip

attrs.query:
What is x? 

What is my favourite ice cream?

content.text: Your favorite ice cream is Mint Chip.
To make Jot function like an AI Chat, you can keep adding AI Blocks under each other. However,
we do not suggest doing this carelessly
.  Jot is really about focusing on writing really good prompts.
Trust us, this makes you better at using AI and AI better at helping you.
P.S. You can choose the type of AI  you want to use in the top right of the AI Block.
Only works once the ContextBrain is Set Up
A context block contains  information from a webpage or web app. It can be  inserted by typing a
/  . This is what it looks like:

on the left contains names of apps and websites.  Use this to select the information you'd like to load into the Jot. This is always defaulted to the most recent app you visited of the selected type.
opens a menu of the recent pages from your browser, you can choose to load any into the context block.
enables  "Run Jot" to be triggered  every time there is new context of the selected source (for example, every time you click on a new email).  We'll get to what "Run Jot" means shortly.
causes the block to refetch the most recent context (App/Web page) of the selected type.
The ContextBrain captures anything you are looking at in your browser and stores it privately on your ContextBrain. The Context Block is how you access it.
This is where the magic happens.
Although Jot's are a great place to write notes, store info, do research, ask questions about your data, etc... you can also create apps with the
runs all of the blocks that have the blue checkmark beside the Run/Refresh button
in sequential order from top to bottom.

attrs.query: Summarize the craziest article  interesting article in 10 words

content.text: "I let Gemini watch my family for the weekend — it got weird" by Jennifer Pattison Tuohy.
Summary: AI assistant Gemini's family observation leads to bizarre, unsettling weekend.

This means you can create sophisticated Jots that function as apps or agents with configured context, live information, chained AI prompts, all running automatically as you use the apps you already use today.
Remember... Jot can also be used as a regular note pad too!

We take privacy very seriously.  For this reason, the Jot ContextBrain is a downloaded app that privately stores information about your applications that you use through the browser.  This is what allows Jot to get data from all of your most important web apps without setting up complex integrations with them.
This does not go to the cloud and lives completely on your computer (hence the short set up!)
It is important to remember that if you create a context block in a Jot, and choose to load it with sensitive information, the information would then be saved in your online Jot profile.

A Trigger is a configured action that fires when certain conditions are met (for example, when you open your calendar).  The Jot Chrome Extension comes with most of what you may need as default triggers.
Every Trigger can be toggled Active (on or off) in the Jot Chrome Extension pop up.

p.s. There is a default trigger called "Other" that will always capture and provide the ability to pull in any page you are looking at.  If you would like more granular control for specific websites, you can create a custom trigger.
You can always press the "Refresh All Active Triggers" to ensure Jot has access to the most up to date information for all active triggers.
This is only necessary if you want Jot to explicitly store and save information from a specific web app.
Go to a webpage that you would like to be able to capture information from.
Open the Jot Chrome Extension and scroll to the bottom.  Click "New Custom Trigger".
Name the Trigger (this is what will be used to identify it in the select box of the Context Block)

The Trigger URL pattern informs Jot ContextBrain when to save the context.  This should be used to specify a specific site, or can be used to send information from a templated website like a facebook page, linkedin profile, etc. Do this by removing the end of the url that represents the unique identifier. For example:
Should be edited in the Trigger URL to:
This way it fires anytime you look at a different profile, not just the original one.
All Triggers start with a general data element that pulls all html.  This can be removed and replaced with selected information by clicking "Add New Data Element".

This will take you back to the page you initially started on and will give you the ability to highlight elements by moving your mouse over them.  Once you click it will ask you to name the data-field. Once named, you can switch back to the configuration tab and you will see the new data element added.
Once saved, refresh the original page and this new Context type will be available in the Context Block.
If the Trigger is not working, it may be because it cant find custom data elements.  In this case delete and recreate the trigger using the default html data element.

attrs.query: Create an example of building a jot for automating research while clicking through to different profiles on linkedin.

content.text: To build a Jot for automating research while clicking through different LinkedIn profiles, follow these steps:
Open the Jot Chrome Extension, scroll to the bottom, and click "Create New Trigger."
Use "Select Data Element" to capture specific profile details (e.g., name, job title, company).
Select the "LinkedIn Profile" trigger from the Select Type Box.
Enable "Start Polling" to automatically fetch data when visiting profiles.
Prompt the AI to summarize key details (e.g., "Summarize this LinkedIn profile's key information").
Check "Include in Run Jot" for both blocks.
or Start Polling to trigger the automation.

[Context Block: LinkedIn Profile]
[AI Block: Summarize profile details]
This setup automatically captures and analyzes LinkedIn profiles as you browse, streamlining research.
If you made it to the bottom, thanks for reading and happy Jotting!
Please do not hesitate to share feature ideas and/or bugs!
